#Text=Thomas Beard
#Text=Thomas Beard
#Text=Thomas Beard
#Text=( died 1632 ) was an English clergyman and theologian , of Puritan views .
#Text=He is known as the author of The Theatre of Gods Judgements , and the schoolmaster of Oliver Cromwell at Huntingdon .
#Text=Life
#Text=He was , it is believed , a native of Huntingdon , but the date of his birth is unknown .
#Text=He received his education at Jesus College , Cambridge , [ 1 ] where he was a sizar and matriculated in 1584 .
#Text=He graduated B.A. in 1588 , M.A. in 1591 , B.D. in 1602 and D.D. in 1614 . [ 2 ]
#Text=He became rector of Kimbolton in 1595 .
#Text=On 21 January 1598 he was collated to the rectory of Hengrave , Suffolk , which he held for a very short time , moving as rector to Aythorp Roothing , Essex , later in the year .
#Text=In 1605 , Beard became master of Huntingdon hospital and grammar school , where he remained for twenty years . [ 2 ]

#Text=It was at this school that Cromwell was educated from around 1604 , and was prepared for entrance to Cambridge ; he acted in Beard 's school plays , and Beard became a friend of the Cromwell family . [ 3 ]
#Text=In March 1614 , Beard asked Sir Robert Bruce Cotton for the rectory of Conington , being tired of teaching .
#Text=He held various rectories with his teaching job , in the end at Wistow where he settled in 1618 for the rest of his life .
#Text=In 1626 , Beard also held a popular lectureship at Huntingdon .
#Text=In 1628 , when Richard Neile went before the House of Commons of England accused of anti-puritan practices , Beard was summoned as a witness against him .
#Text=Cromwell 's speech in the debate on the subject covers his likely testimony ( the parliament was dissolved before Beard could testify ) .

#Text=Beard had been appointed in 1617 to preach a sermon on the Sunday after Easter in London , in which , according to custom , he was to recapitulate three sermons previously preached before the lord mayor from an open pulpit in Spital Square .
#Text=William Alabaster
#Text=was the preacher whom Beard had to follow , but he announced his intention of exposing Alabaster 's support of certain tenets of popery .

#Text=On Cromwell 's account , Neile as Beard 's diocesan bishop ( diocese of Lincoln ) told him not to preach against Alabaster ; and reprimanded him later when on the advice of Nicholas Felton he did so .
#Text=In 1630 he was made a justice of the peace for the county .
#Text=He was married , and had children by Mary Heriman ; they were married 9 July 1628 .
#Text=Edward Wedlake Brayley
#Text=in his Beauties of England and Wales recorded the inscription on a brass in the nave of All Saints ' Church , Huntingdon , to Beard 's memory .
#Text=In 1633 Archbishop William Laud succeeded in putting the lectureship down .
#Text=Works
#Text=Beard 's earliest and most famous book first appeared in 1597 ; [ 4 ] a work in the tradition of John Foxe ' s Acts and Monuments , it was popular , plagiarised and pirated . [ 5 ]

#Text=It was itself translated , in part , from the Histoires memorables des grans et merveilleux jugemens et punitions de Dieu by Jean de Chassanion ( 1531 – 1598 ) , a Huguenot pastor from Monistrol-sur-Loire , [ 6 ] from which it derives its account of the bullet catch trick . [ 7 ] [ 8 ]

#Text=Chassingnon 's book provided hundreds of the examples , while Beard added in a scattering from other sources closer to home : Foxe , John Stowe , Raphael Holinshed , pamphlets and ballads . [ 9 ]
#Text=Beard 's exposition of the workings of Providence against sinners and persecutors has been called " theatrical moralism " . [ 10 ]
#Text=It was in the Theatre of Judgement that first appeared an account of Christopher Marlowe ' s death ; Beard takes Marlowe to be the first modern atheist . [ 11 ]
#Text=Other editions followed in 1612 and 1631 , with additions , and a fourth edition in folio of 1648 .
#Text=In 1625 he published a work on the Pope as Antichrist . [ 12 ]
#Text=Beard left in manuscript an Evangelical Tragoedie : or , A Harmonie of the Passion of Christ , according to the four Evangelistes .
#Text=A Latin comedy Pedantius [ 13 ] has been attributed to him , but also to Walter Hawkesworth , Anthony Wingfield and ( by modern scholars ) to Edward Forsett . [ 14 ]
